subject: Leadership
title: Suffragette Leadership
description: A quick, practical guide to Suffragette Leadership.

hook.text: Women fought for decades to vote. The struggle required multiple leadership styles working in concert.

buildup.text: Pankhurst used militant tactics. Fawcett used peaceful persuasion. Together they built unstoppable pressure for change.

discovery.text: Social movements need both radicals and moderates. Radicals shift the window. Moderates negotiate the deals.

twist.text: The movement faced backlash, imprisonment, and force-feeding. Progress required enduring pain most won't accept.

climax.text: Movement leadership is collective, not individual. No single leader wins. The network of committed people does.

punchline.text: They didn't ask for permission. They demanded what was right.

quiz.question: Why do social movements need both radicals and moderates?
options: They don't; one approach is always enough
Radicals shift the window while moderates negotiate change
Moderates are more important than radicals
